cupolaPhotos.title: Earth's Blue Marble from Cupola
cupolaPhotos.description: A breathtaking view of Earth captured through the ISS Cupola windows, showing the planet's blue oceans, white clouds, and thin atmosphere.
facts: This photo was taken at an altitude of 408 kilometers above Earth
The ISS travels at 27,600 km/h, completing one orbit every 90 minutes
The blue color comes from sunlight scattering in Earth's atmosphere

cupolaPhotos.title: Hurricane from Space
cupolaPhotos.description: A powerful hurricane captured from the Cupola, showing the distinctive eye wall and spiral bands of clouds.
facts: Hurricanes can be tracked from space 5-7 days before they make landfall
The eye of a hurricane can be 20-50 kilometers in diameter
ISS data helps improve hurricane prediction models

cupolaPhotos.title: City Lights at Night
cupolaPhotos.description: The eastern United States illuminated at night, showcasing human civilization from space through the Cupola windows.
facts: Light pollution patterns reveal population density and development
LED streetlights appear more blue-white compared to older yellow lights
Night photography helps scientists study urbanization trends

cupolaPhotos.title: Aurora Borealis
cupolaPhotos.description: The Northern Lights dance across Earth's atmosphere as seen from the ISS Cupola, creating a spectacular green curtain of light.
facts: Auroras occur when solar particles interact with Earth's magnetic field
The ISS often flies directly through aurora displays
Green auroras occur at altitudes of 100-300 km above Earth

cupolaPhotos.title: Sahara Desert Patterns
cupolaPhotos.description: Intricate sand dune patterns in the Sahara Desert captured through the Cupola, showing natural geological formations.
facts: The Sahara covers 9 million square kilometers
Desert dust travels across the Atlantic to fertilize Amazon rainforests
ISS helps track sandstorm movements and climate impacts

cupolaPhotos.title: Amazon Rainforest
cupolaPhotos.description: The Amazon rainforest and its winding rivers as seen from the Cupola, highlighting Earth's biodiversity hotspot.
facts: The Amazon produces 20% of the world's oxygen
ISS monitors deforestation with 30-meter resolution
The rainforest covers 5.5 million square kilometers

cupolaPhotos.title: Himalayan Peaks
cupolaPhotos.description: Snow-capped Himalayan mountains photographed from the Cupola, showing Earth's highest peaks reaching toward space.
facts: Mount Everest is 8.85 km high - visible from the ISS at 408 km altitude
Himalayan glaciers provide water for 2 billion people
ISS monitors glacial retreat due to climate change

cupolaPhotos.title: Earth's Terminator Line
cupolaPhotos.description: The boundary between day and night on Earth captured from the Cupola, showing the transition from sunlight to darkness.
facts: The terminator line moves at 1,670 km/h at the equator
Astronauts see 16 sunrises and sunsets every day
The thin blue line is Earth's atmosphere protecting life below
